<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8.0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000;WIDTH:10%">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Average Monthly Active Accounts for a given period refers to the number of registered accounts that were logged in to these games at least once during the period.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(2)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Quarterly Aggregate Active Paying Accounts for a given period refers to the number of accounts from which game points are utilized at least once during the quarter.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	73
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage76"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D62578D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Web games
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our primary Web games prior to our sale of Shenzhen 7Road in August 2015 were Wartune and DDTank. Our revenues generated from Web games were
	$45.9 million for 2015, compared to $100.7 million and $135.7 million, respectively, for 2014 and 2013. The year-over-year decrease in Web game revenues for 2015 was $54.8 million, mainly due to a decrease in Web game revenues upon the completion of
	the sale of the 7Road business during the third quarter of 2015. The year-over-year decrease in Web games revenues for 2014 was $35.0 million, mainly due to decreased revenues in China from Wartune and DDTank, which had reached a mature phase in
	their operation.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<U>
	Online Advertising Revenues
</U>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Online advertising revenues, which consist mainly of revenues generated from the 17173.com Website, were $57.8 million for 2015, compared to
	$59.0 million and $50.0 million, respectively, for 2014 and 2013. The year-over-year decrease in online advertising revenues for 2015 was $1.2 million. The year-over-year increase in online advertising revenues for 2014 was $9.0 million, mainly due
	to an increase in the utilization rate of advertising on the 17173.com Website as a result of improvements made to the advertising sales function.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<U>
	IVAS Revenues
</U>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our IVAS
	revenues were $24.4 million for 2015, compared to $22.4 million and $5.4 million, respectively, for 2014 and 2013. The year-over-year increase in IVAS revenues for 2015 was $2.0 million, mainly due to higher revenues from PC and mobile products
	offered by our platform channel business. The year-over-year increase in IVAS revenues for 2014 was $17.0 million, mainly due to the incremental revenues from the Dolphin Browser and Raidcall from their PC and mobile products.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<U>
	Others Revenues
</U>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Others
	revenues, which consist of revenues from cinema advertising, were $42.6 million for 2015, compared to $21.9 million and $13.3 million, respectively, for 2014 and 2013. The year-over-year increase in others revenues for 2015 was $20.7 million, mainly
	due to strong growth in China&#146;s movie and cinema industry in general, and improvements made to our advertising sales function. The year-over-year increase for 2014 was $8.6 million, mainly due to strong growth in China&#146;s movie and cinema
	industry in general.
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_12"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">

<P STYLE="BORDER-TOP:3.00PX DOUBLE #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<P STYLE="BORDER-TOP:3.00PX DOUBLE #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<P STYLE="BORDER-TOP:3.00PX DOUBLE #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<P STYLE="BORDER-TOP:3.00PX DOUBLE #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<P STYLE="BORDER-TOP:3.00PX DOUBLE #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<P STYLE="BORDER-TOP:3.00PX DOUBLE #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Cost of online game revenues was $156.3 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, compared to $142.5
	million and $93.3 million, respectively, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013. The year-over-year increase in cost of online game revenues for 2015 was $13.8 million. The increase mainly consisted of a $53.8 million increase in
	revenue-sharing payments to mobile application stores, a $19.0 million decrease in salary and benefits expense, a $6.1 million decrease in PRC business tax and value-added tax, a $5.8 million decrease in bandwidth leasing costs, a $3.8 million
	decrease in depreciation expenses and a $2.7 million decrease in revenue-sharing payments to third-party developers. The year-over-year increase in cost of online game revenues for 2014 was $49.2 million. The increase mainly consisted of a $24.6
	million increase in revenue-sharing payments to mobile application stores, a $7.5 million increase in revenue-sharing payments to third-party developers, a $9.1 million increase in salary and benefits expense, and a $1.5 million increase in
	bandwidth leasing costs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	74
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage77"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D62578D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Cost of online advertising revenues was $11.6 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015,
	compared to $14.8 million and $13.8 million, respectively, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013. The year-over-year decrease in cost of online advertising revenues for 2015 was $3.3 million. The decrease mainly consisted of a $1.8
	million decrease in salary and benefits expense, a $0.6 million decrease in advertising design costs and a $0.3 million decrease in depreciation expenses. The year-over-year increase in cost of online advertising revenues for 2014 was $1.0 million.
	The increase was mainly due to increases in bandwidth leasing costs and salary and benefits expense.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Cost of IVAS revenues was $19.6
	million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, compared to $23.0 million and $1.8 million, respectively, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013. The year-over-year decrease in cost of IVAS revenues for 2015 was $3.4 million. The
	decrease mainly consisted of a $5.0 million decrease in bandwidth leasing costs and a $0.8 million increase in revenue-sharing payments to third-party developers and service providers. The year-over-year increase in cost of IVAS revenues for 2014
	was $21.2 million. The increase mainly consisted of a $12.5 million increase in bandwidth leasing costs and a $5.2 million increase in revenue-sharing payments to third-party developers and service providers.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Cost of others revenues were $29.2 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, compared to $21.5 million and $17.5 million,
	respectively, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013. The year-over-year increase in cost of others revenues for 2015 was $7.7 million. The increase was mainly due to an increase in purchases of pre-film screening advertising slots. The
	year-over-year increase in cost of others revenues for 2014 was $4.0 million. The increase was mainly due to an increase in purchases of pre-film screening advertising slots.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Gross Profit
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As a
	result of the foregoing, our gross profit was $544.9 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, compared to $553.4 million and $611.4 million, respectively, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013.
	Our gross margin was 71.5%, 73.3% and 82.9%, respectively, for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015,&nbsp;December&nbsp;31, 2014 and December&nbsp;31, 2013. The decrease in gross margin was mainly due to a change in the revenue mix as we launched
	new mobile games and licensed PC games that typically require additional revenue sharing costs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Operating Expenses
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our operating expenses consist of product development expenses, sales and marketing expenses, general and administrative expenses, and goodwill
	impairment and impairment of intangibles acquired as part of the acquisition of a business. Share-based compensation expenses are included in product development expenses, sales and marketing expenses, and general and administrative expenses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following table sets forth our product development expenses, sales and marketing expenses, general and administrative expenses, and
	goodwill impairment and impairment of intangibles acquired as part of the acquisition of a business, both in absolute amount and as a percentage of total revenues for the periods indicated:
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Product Development Expenses
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our product development expenses consist primarily of salary and benefits expense, including share-based compensation expense, for personnel
	engaged in the development of our game development platform and our games, and content and license expenses relating to our games. Product development expenses decreased to $170.6 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to $194.1
	million and $119.9 million, respectively, for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013. The decrease in product development expenses for 2015 was mainly due to a decrease in salary and benefits expense as a result of a reduction in our
	workforce. The increase in product development expenses for 2014 mainly due to an increase in salary and benefits expense. Product development expenses constituted 22.4%, 25.7% and 16.3%, respectively, of our total revenues for the years ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	75
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage78"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D62578D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Sales and Marketing Expenses
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our sales and marketing expenses consist primarily of expenses for advertisement and promotion, and salary and benefits expense, including
	share-based compensation expense, for our sales and marketing personnel. Sales and marketing expenses decreased to $92.4 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to $241.3 million and $128.8 million, respectively, for the years
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013. The decrease in sales and marketing expenses for 2015 was mainly due to a significant reduction in marketing and promotional spending for mobile Internet products. The increase in sales and marketing expenses
	for 2014 mainly reflected higher advertising costs for promotion of the platform channel business. Sales and marketing expenses constituted 12.1%, 32.0% and 17.5%, respectively, of our total revenues for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014
	and 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	General and Administrative Expenses
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our general and administrative expenses consist primarily of salary and benefits expense, including share-based compensation expense, for
	management, finance and administrative personnel, and professional service fees. General and administrative expenses increased to $80.3 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to $107.5 million and $57.2&nbsp;million,
	respectively, for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013. The decrease in general and administrative expenses for 2015 was primarily due to a decrease in salary and benefits expense as a result of a reduction in our workforce. The increase
	in general and administrative expenses for 2014 was primarily due to an increase in head count and related salary and benefit expense. General and administrative expenses constituted 10.5%, 14.2% and 7.8%, respectively, of our total revenues for the
	years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Goodwill impairment and impairment of intangible assets acquired as part of
	acquisition of a business
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2015, we recognized $40.3 million of goodwill impairment and impairment of intangible assets acquired as
	part of the acquisition of a business. The $40.3 million impairment loss consisted primarily of a $29.6 million impairment loss for goodwill and an $8.9 million impairment loss for intangible assets related to the Dolphin Browser, as a result of our
	managements&#146; assessment that the expected synergies between our other mobile internet products and the Dolphin Browser were not likely to materialize.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2014, we recognized $52.3 million of goodwill impairment and impairment of intangible assets acquired as part of the acquisition of a
	business. This $52.3 million impairment loss consisted primarily of a $33.8 million impairment loss for goodwill and a $15.3 million impairment loss for intangible assets related to RaidCall, as a result of our management&#146;s assessment that the
	impairment existed based on its conclusion that RaidCall was unable to provide expected synergies with our online games business.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In
	2013, there was no goodwill impairment and impairment of intangible assets acquired as part of acquisition of a business.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, unrecognized share-based compensation expense is $23.6 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Operating Profit/(Loss)
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As a result of the foregoing, we had an operating profit of $161.3 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, compared to an operating
	loss of $41.7 million and an operating profit of $305.5 million, respectively, for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;

	76

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D62578D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Foreign Currency Exchange/(Loss) Gain
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, foreign currency exchange gain was $3.0 million, compared to foreign currency exchange loss of $0.7
	million and foreign currency exchange loss of $5.9 million, respectively, for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Interest Income
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 interest income was $23.8 million, compared to $26.1 million and $28.5 million, respectively, for the
	years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and December&nbsp;31, 2013. The decrease was primarily due to a decrease in our average cash balance for the year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Interest Expense
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, interest expense was $8.3 million, compared to $6.5 million and $8.8 million, respectively, for the
	years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and December&nbsp;31, 2013. The increase in 2015 was primarily due to an increase in our average balance of the bank loans. The decrease in 2014 was primarily due to a decrease in our average balance of the bank
	loans.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Other Income/(Expenses)
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, other income/(expense) represents other income of $65.0 million, compared to other income of
	$4.1&nbsp;million and other expense of $3.6&nbsp;million, respectively, for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and December&nbsp;31, 2013. The year-over-year increase in other income for 2015 was mainly due to our disposition of Shenzhen 7Road.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Income Tax Expense
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Income tax expense was $54.1 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, compared to $2.5 million and $36.4 million, respectively, for
	the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and December&nbsp;31, 2013. The increase in 2015 was mainly due to an increase in our income before income tax expense. The decrease in 2014 was mainly due to a decrease in our income before income tax expense.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Net Income Attributable to Mezzanine Classified Non-controlling Interest
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In accordance with ASC subtopic 480-10, we calculated, on an accumulative basis from the acquisition date, (i)&nbsp;the amount of accretion
	that would increase the balance of non-controlling interest to its estimated redemption value over the period from the date of the 7Road acquisition to the earliest redemption date of the non-controlling interest and (ii)&nbsp;the amount of net
	profit attributable to non-controlling shareholders of 7Road based on their ownership percentage. The carrying value of the non-controlling interest as mezzanine equity was adjusted by an accumulative amount equal to the higher of (i)&nbsp;and (ii).
	On June&nbsp;5, 2013 Changyou acquired of the non-controlling interest in 7Road. Accordingly, no accretion charge has been recorded since the acquisition. The accretion charge was $nil, $nil and $17.8 million, respectively, for the years ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, December&nbsp;31, 2014 and December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Net Loss Attributable to Non-controlling Interests
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net loss attributable to non-controlling interests was $22.2 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015. Non-controlling
	interests consist of non-controlling interests in RaidCall and MoboTap.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Net Income/(Loss) Attributable to Changyou.com Limited
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As a result of the foregoing, we had net income attributable to Changyou.com Limited of $212.8 million for the year ended December
	31, 2015, compared to a net loss of $3.4 million and net income of $268.6 million, respectively, for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</P>
</EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>
<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Liquidity and Capital Resources
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
<U>
	Significant
	Cash-Related Activities
</U>
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We have financed our operations primarily through cash flows from operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2007, Sohu transferred to us all of the assets and operations relating to its PC games business unit, and we assumed all the liabilities
	associated with Sohu&#146;s PC games business unit.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	77
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage80"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D62578D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In April 2009, we received net proceeds of $54.7 million from our initial public offering.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On April&nbsp;1, 2009, we declared a cash dividend of $96.8 million payable solely to Sohu.com (Game) Limited, which is an indirect
	wholly-owned subsidiary of Sohu.com Inc. In the fourth quarter of 2009, after receiving approval from the PRC government, we paid the dividend to Sohu.com (Game) Limited. In connection with such dividend we also paid PRC withholding tax of $5.0
	million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On August&nbsp;6, 2012 our Board of Directors declared, and on September&nbsp;21, 2012 we paid to our shareholders, a special
	one-time cash dividend in the total amount of $200.9 million, of which $136.3 million was paid to Sohu.com (Game) Limited.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2012
	and 2013, we drew down loans from offshore banks in an aggregate amount of $410.3 million, which were secured by an equivalent or greater amount of RMB deposits in onshore branches of those banks, totaling $424.7 million. As of December&nbsp;31,
	2013, $307.0 million of the loan amount carried a floating rate of interest based on the London Inter-Bank Offered Rate and $103.3 million carried a fixed rate of interest.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2014, we drew down loans from offshore banks in an aggregate amount of $370.0 million. The loans were secured by an equivalent or
	greater amount of RMB deposits in onshore branches of those banks, totaling $417.4 million. As of December&nbsp;31, 2014, the entire loan amount carried a floating rate of interest based on the London Inter-Bank Offered Rate.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2015, we drew down loans from offshore banks in an aggregate amount of $344.5 million. The loans were secured by RMB deposits totaling
	RMB2.3 billion (or $354.7 million) in onshore branches of those banks. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, the entire loan amount carried a floating rate of interest based on the London Inter-Bank Offered Rate. We plan to repay the loans in full during
	2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
<U>
	Liquidity Sources and Balances
</U>
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We had cash and cash equivalents and short-term investments of approximately $744.4 million, $412.4 million and $551.3 million, respectively,
	as of December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013. Cash equivalents primarily consist of time deposits with maturities of three months or less and money market funds, which are stated at fair market value.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We believe our current liquidity and capital resources are sufficient to meet anticipated working capital needs (net cash used in operating
	activities), commitments and capital expenditures over the next twelve months.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Operating Activities
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net cash provided by operating activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 was $213.3 million, which was primarily attributable to net
	income of $190.6 million, adjusted by non-cash items consisting of depreciation and amortization of $41.1 million and goodwill impairment and impairment of intangible assets acquired as part of the acquisition of a business of $40.3 million, offset
	by gain on disposal of subsidiaries and other long term investments of $53.7 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net cash provided by operating activities for the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 was $50.3 million, which was primarily attributable to our net loss of $21.2 million, adjusted by non-cash items consisting of depreciation and amortization of $65.2 million, goodwill impairment and impairment of
	intangible assets acquired as part of the acquisition of a business of $52.3 million, and share-based compensation expense of $4.1 million, offset by a deferred tax credit of $21.0 million and change in other assets and liabilities of $31.9 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	78
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage81"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D62578D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net cash provided by operating activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 was $358.6
	million, which was primarily attributable to the following factors: (i)&nbsp;net income of $286.4 million, (ii)&nbsp;depreciation and amortization of $42.4 million (iii)&nbsp;change in current assets and liabilities of $21.0 million; and
	(iv)&nbsp;deferred tax expense of $5.4 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Investing Activities
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, net cash used in investing activities was $3.9 million and was primarily attributable to
	consideration received from disposal of subsidiaries of $184.3 million and cash proceeds relating to restricted time deposits of $40.3 million, offset by matching loans to Sohu and SoEasy, of $176.6 million, purchases of intangible assets and other
	assets for $23.2 million and purchases of fixed assets for an aggregate of $12.4 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, net
	cash used in investing activities was $330.5 million, which was primarily attributable to purchases of short-term investments of $186.5 million, cash paid for business acquisitions (net of cash acquired) of $86.5 million, purchases of intangible
	assets and other assets for $35.1 million, and purchases of fixed assets for $24.2 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013,
	net cash used in investing activities was $322.7 million, which was primarily attributable to purchase of fixed assets of $61.6 million, purchase of intangible assets and other assets of $34.1 million, cash paid in relation to restricted time
	deposits of $168.6 million and cash paid for business acquisitions (net of cash acquired) of $109.7 million, partially offset by a cash inflow consisting of the proceeds from short-term investments of $51.2 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Financing Activities
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, net cash provided by financing activities was $142.9 million, which was primarily due to matching loans from related parties of $182.9 million, offset by repayments of loans to offshore banks of $25.5 million
	and payment of $14.5 million for repurchases under our share repurchase program.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, net cash used
	in financing activities was $46.6 million, which was primarily due to repayments of loans to offshore banks of $410.2 million, payment of $3.6 million for repurchases under our share repurchase program and payment of contingent consideration of
	$2.8&nbsp;million, offset by proceeds of loans from offshore banks of $370.0 million,.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, net
	cash provided by financing activities was $130.1 million, which was primarily due to our receipt of the proceeds of loans from offshore banks of $167.0 million, and our payment of contingent consideration of $19.7&nbsp;million and payment of $17.2
	million for repurchases under our share repurchase program.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
<U>
	PRC Restrictions Related to Our VIE Structure
</U>
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	To fund any cash requirements from time to time, we may need to rely on dividends, loans or advances made by our principal PRC subsidiaries. We
	conduct most of our operations in PRC through our principal VIEs Gamease, Guanyou Gamespace, Shanghai ICE and Wuhan Baina Information, which generate most of our operating revenues. As our VIEs are not owned by our subsidiaries, they are not able to
	make dividend payments to our subsidiaries. Instead, our subsidiaries AmazGame, Gamespace and Beijing Baina Technology have entered into a number of contracts with their corresponding VIEs to provide services to such VIEs in return for cash
	payments. In order for us to receive any dividends, loans or advances from AmazGame, Gamespace or Beijing Baina Technology, or to distribute any dividends to our shareholders and ADS holders from operating income sources, we will need to rely on
	these payments made from our principal VIEs to these principal PRC subsidiaries. Depending on the nature of services provided by these PRC subsidiaries to their corresponding VIEs, certain of these payments are subject to PRC taxes, including
	business taxes and VAT, which effectively reduce the amount that a PRC subsidiary receives from its corresponding VIE. In addition, the PRC government could impose restrictions on such payments or change the tax rates applicable to such payments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
<U>
	PRC Profit Appropriation, Withholding Tax on Dividends and Regulation of Foreign Currency Exchange
</U>
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Regulations in the PRC currently permit payment of dividends of a PRC company, only out of accumulated profits as determined in accordance with
	accounting standards and regulations in China. Our China-based WFOEs are also required to set aside at least 10% of its after-tax profit, determined in accordance with PRC accounting standards, each year to its general reserves until the cumulative
	amount reaches 50% of its registered capital. These reserves are not distributable as cash dividends, or as loans or advances. Our WFOEs may also allocate a portion of their after-tax profits, as determined by its Board of Directors, to their staff
	welfare and bonus funds, which may not be distributed to us.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Furthermore, under regulations of the SAFE, the RMB is not convertible into
	foreign currencies for capital account items, such as loans, repatriation of investments and investments outside of China, unless the prior approval of the SAFE is obtained and prior registration with the SAFE is made.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	79
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage82"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D62578D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Any dividends paid by any of our PRC subsidiaries to its direct holding company in Hong Kong will
	be subject to a withholding tax at a rate of at least 5% and could be as high as 10%, which will reduce the amount of cash available for distribution to us. See &#147;Risk Factors&#151;Risks related to Doing Business in China&#151;There are
	significant uncertainties under the Corporate Income Tax Law of the PRC, or the CIT Law, regarding our PRC enterprise income tax liabilities, such as tax on dividends paid to us by our PRC subsidiaries. The CIT Law also contains uncertainties
	regarding possible PRC withholding tax on any dividends we pay to our overseas corporate shareholders and gains realized from the transfer of our shares by our overseas corporate shareholders
<I>
	.
</I>
	&#148; in Item&nbsp;3.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We do not expect any of such restrictions or taxes to have a material impact on our ability to meet our cash obligations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We believe that our existing cash is sufficient to sustain our operations for at least the next twelve months.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Capital Expenditures
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our capital expenditures include the purchase of fixed assets, intangible assets and other assets. Our capital expenditures were $35.6 million,
	$59.4 million and $95.7 million, respectively, for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In August 2010, we entered into
	an agreement for the purchase and development of an office building of approximately 56,549 square meters in Beijing to serve as our headquarters, for consideration of approximately $171 million. We occupied the office building in December 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Research and Development, Patents and Licenses, etc.
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our research and development efforts are primarily to keep pace with technological advances in order to make our online game development
	capabilities and our games competitive in the market. Moreover, we also focus on the improvement of our licensed games. We intend to further expand our internal game development capabilities and license more new games that are attractive to users.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Off-balance Sheet Arrangements
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We have not entered into any financial guarantees or other commitments to guarantee the payment obligations of third parties. We have not
	entered into any derivative contracts that are indexed to our shares and classified as shareholder&#146;s equity, or that are not reflected in our consolidated financial statements. Furthermore, we do not have any retained or contingent interest in
	assets transferred to an unconsolidated entity that serves as credit, liquidity or market risk support to such entity. We do not have any variable interest in any unconsolidated entity that provides financing, liquidity, market risk or credit
	support to us or that engages in leasing, hedging or product development services with us.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D62578D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	IMPACT OF RECENTLY ISSUED ACCOUNTING STANDARDS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On May 28, 2014, the FASB and IASB issued their long-awaited converged standard on the recognition of revenue from contracts with customers.
	The standard is intended to improve the financial reporting of revenue and improve comparability of the top line in financial statements globally. The FASB is amending the FASB Accounting Standards Codification and creating a new Topic 606, Revenue
	from Contracts with Customers, to supersede the revenue recognition requirements in Topic 605, Revenue Recognition, and most industry-specific guidance throughout the Industry Topics of the Codification. Additionally, the amendments supersede some
	cost guidance included in Subtopic 605-35, Revenue Recognition &#151; Construction &#151; Type and Production &#151; Type Contracts. For a public business entity, the amendments are effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December 15,
	2016, including interim periods within that reporting period. Early application is not permitted. We are currently evaluating the impact on our consolidated financial statements of adopting this guidance.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In February 2015, the FASB issued Consolidation (Topic 810) &#151; Amendments to the Consolidation Analysis. The amendments in Topic 810
	respond to stakeholders&#146; concerns about the current accounting for consolidation of variable interest entities, by changing aspects of the analysis that a reporting entity must perform to determine whether it should consolidate such entities.
	Under the amendments, all reporting entities are within the scope of Subtopic 810-10, Consolidation &#151; Overall, including limited partnerships and similar legal entities, unless a scope exception applies. The amendments are intended to be an
	improvement to current U.S. GAAP, as they simplify the codification of FASB Statement No. 167, Amendments to FASB Interpretation No. 46(R), with changes including reducing the number of consolidation models through the elimination of the indefinite
	deferral of Statement 167 and placing more emphasis on risk of loss when determining a controlling financial interest. The amendments are effective for publicly-traded companies for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2015, and for interim
	periods within those fiscal years. Earlier adoption is permitted. We are currently evaluating the impact on our consolidated financial statements of adopting this guidance.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In September 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-16, Simplifying the Accounting for Measurement-Period Adjustments, which eliminates the
	requirement for acquirers in a business combination to account for measurement-period adjustments retrospectively. Instead, acquirers must recognize measurement-period adjustments during the period in which they determine the amounts, including the
	effect on earnings of any amounts that would have been recorded in previous periods if the accounting had been completed at the acquisition date. This update is effective for interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2015, with early
	adoption permitted. The implementation of this update is not expected to have any material impact on our condensed consolidated financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In November 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-17, Income Taxes (Topic 740): Balance Sheet Classification of Deferred Taxes, which simplifies
	the presentation of deferred income taxes by requiring that deferred tax assets and liabilities be classified as noncurrent on the balance sheet. The amendments in this update are effective for financial statements issued for annual periods
	beginning after December 15, 2016, and interim periods within those annual periods. All short-term deferred tax assets and liabilities will be reclassified to long-term assets and liabilities upon adoption of this update.
</P>
</EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
</EFX_OPERATING_AND_FINANCIAL_REVIEW>

	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Member of the audit committee of our Board of Directors.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Dr.
</I>
<I>
	&nbsp;
</I>
<I>
	Charles
	Zhang
</I>
	is the Chairman of our Board of Directors. Dr.&nbsp;Zhang is the founder of Sohu and has been Chairman of the Board and CEO of Sohu since August 1996. Prior to founding Sohu, Dr.&nbsp;Zhang worked for Internet Securities Inc., or ISI, and
	helped establish its China operations. Prior to joining ISI, he worked as Massachusetts Institute of Technology&#146;s liaison officer with China. Dr.&nbsp;Zhang has a Ph.D. in Experimental Physics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and
	a Bachelor of science degree from Tsinghua University in Beijing.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Carol Yu
</I>
	is our Co-Chief Executive Officer and was appointed by
	our Board as one of our directors on February&nbsp;7, 2015 to fill the vacancy created by the resignation of Mr.&nbsp;Tao Wang as a director effective January&nbsp;15, 2015. Ms.&nbsp;Yu is President and Chief Financial Officer of our ultimate parent
	Sohu.com Inc. Ms.&nbsp;Yu joined Sohu.com Inc. in March 2004 as its Chief Financial Officer. From March 1995 until November 2000, Ms.&nbsp;Carol Yu served as Senior Vice-President Investment Banking of Donaldson Lufkin&nbsp;&amp; Jenrette Securities
	Corporation in Hong Kong. Ms.&nbsp;Carol Yu also worked with Arthur Andersen Hong Kong and Beijing for ten years and was a partner of the Audit Division, holding the position of General Manager of Arthur Andersen-Hua Qiang, the joint venture
	accounting firm formed between Arthur Andersen and the Ministry of Finance in China.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	81
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage84"></A>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Dewen Chen
</I>
	is our Co-Chief Executive Officer and was one of the principal founders of our
	online game business. Mr.&nbsp;Chen joined Sohu in 2005 as a business manager, responsible for building our sales team for games products and starting May 2006, Mr.&nbsp;Chen was in charge of the overall marketing, promotion, sales and channel
	distribution of Sohu&#146;s games products. Prior to our carve out from Sohu, Mr.&nbsp;Chen was the Director of Marketing&nbsp;&amp; Operations of the client-end installed MMORPG business of Sohu. From April 2000 to April 2005, Mr.&nbsp;Chen worked
	at Shanghai Hua Teng Software System Co. Ltd. as a pre-sale technology consultant and sale manager of its business with banks. Prior to that, Mr.&nbsp;Chen had worked with Fujian Shi Da Computer Group as a software engineer, project manager and
	later the Director of the Technology Department at its Shanghai branch office. Mr.&nbsp;Chen received a bachelor&#146;s degree in Computer Engineering from Xi&#146;an Jiaotong University.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Xiaojian Hong
</I>
	is our Chief Operating Officer and was one of the principal founders of our MMORPG business. Mr.&nbsp;Hong has
	significant experience in the security, efficiency and stability of online games software and operations. Prior to our carve-out from Sohu, Mr.&nbsp;Hong was a Senior Manager of Sohu and played a key role in building Sohu&#146;s MMORPG software
	development division and was responsible for strategic planning for technology framework design and module development for our MMORPG business. From 2004 to 2005, Mr.&nbsp;Hong worked at Sina and was a research and development manager of its iGAME
	project. From 2001 to 2004, Mr.&nbsp;Hong was the Manager of Research and Development of Beijing Tian Ren Interactive Software Technologies Co. Ltd., responsible for in-house digital games design and development and introduction, distribution and
	localization of popular overseas games products. From 1999 to 2001, Mr.&nbsp;Hong was a project manager of Object Software (Beijing) Limited. Mr.&nbsp;Hong received a bachelor&#146;s degree in Engineering from Beijing Technology University.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Jasmine Zhou
</I>
	was appointed as our Chief Financial Officer on February&nbsp;7, 2015. Ms.&nbsp;Zhou has been with Sohu since August 2003
	and has extensive experience in capital markets and participated in all mergers, acquisitions and other capital related transactions of Sohu, including our carve-out from Sohu and our initial public offering in 2009 and Tencent&#146;s strategic
	investment in and business collaboration with Sohu&#146;s subsidiary Sogou Inc. Ms.&nbsp;Zhou received her bachelor&#146;s degree in law from Renmin University of China, an LL.M. degree from the University of Sydney, and a Dual Executive MBA degree
	from Tsinghua University and INSEAD.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Dave De Yang
</I>
	has served as an independent director and a member of our audit committee since
	April 2009. Mr.&nbsp;Yang has been serving a role of CFO for Reckitt Benckiser North Asia region including China, Hong Kong, Taiwan, Japan and Korea since September 2012. Prior to this role, Mr.&nbsp;Yang had worked for McDonald&#146;s Corporation
	as a senior financial director, including an international assignment as the Corporate Controller of McDonald&#146;s China for three and half years. Prior to such role, he served as acting controller of McDonald&#146;s India and Indonesia and as a
	senior director of McDonald&#146;s Corporation in Asia Pacific, Middle East and Africa division where he oversaw the development and supervision of financial strategy and policy. Prior to joining McDonald&#146;s Corporation, Mr.&nbsp;Yang worked in
	the U.S. business unit of Ernst&nbsp;&amp; Young LLP for seven years in various positions, including as a group manager. During Mr.&nbsp;Yang&#146;s tenure at Ernst&nbsp;&amp; Young LLP, he focused on business risk management consultation, corporate
	M&amp;A, restructuring of corporate internal management processes, internal audits, risk assessment, control system designs, and auditing of corporate financial statements, primarily for Fortune 500 companies. Mr.&nbsp;Yang has a master of business
	administration degree from the City University of New York, a master&#146;s degree in Management and Engineering from the Graduate School of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing, and a bachelor&#146;s degree in Physics from the University of
	Science and Technology of China. Mr.&nbsp;Yang is a member of the U.S. Institute of Certified Internal Auditors, the Institute of Certified Public Accountants and the Institute of Certified Management Accountants.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Dr.
</I>
<I>
	&nbsp;
</I>
<I>
	Xiao Chen
</I>
	has served as an independent director and a member of our audit committee since August 2012.
	Dr.&nbsp;Chen has been an accounting professor at the School of Economics and Management at Tsinghua University since 1997. For the past 18 years, he has been teaching and conducting academic research in the fields of accounting and taxation at
	Tsinghua University. From August 2007 to July 2014, Dr.&nbsp;Chen served on the board of directors and as the chairman of the audit committee of Noah Education Holdings Ltd, a public company listed on the New York Stock Exchange. Since 2011, he has
	also served as an independent director of China First Chemical Holdings Ltd, a company listed on Hong Kong Stock Exchange. Prior to 2012, he served as an independent director of five public companies listed on the Shanghai and Shenzhen Stock
	Exchanges. Since November 2012, he has served as an independent director of Jintin Pharmaceutical Group Ltd., which is listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. Since January 2015, he has served as an independent director of Beijing ChineseAll Digital
	Publishing Co., Ltd., which is listed on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange. Dr.&nbsp;Chen received a bachelor&#146;s degree in engineering from the Wuhan Institute of Chemical Engineering in 1983, a master&#146;s degree in management from the University
	of Science and Technology of China in 1989, and a Ph.D. in economics from Tulane University in 1996.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D62578D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Mr.
</I>
<I>
	&nbsp;
</I>
<I>
	Charles Chan
</I>
	has served as an independent director and a member of
	our audit committee since September 2013. Mr.&nbsp;Chan joined Arthur Andersen Canada in 1977 and was admitted to the AA Worldwide Partnership in 1988. Transferred to Arthur Andersen Hong Kong/China in 1994, Mr.&nbsp;Chan was Head of Audit and
	Business Advisory Service for Greater China. After Arthur Andersen merged with PricewaterhouseCoopers, or PwC, in 2002, Mr.&nbsp;Chan assumed management positions at PwC, including as a partner and as a member of various committees. Mr.&nbsp;Chan
	qualified as a Chartered Accountant in Canada in 1980 and as a Certified Public Accountant in Hong Kong in 1995.He has extensive experience in serving major clients listed in various major capital markets through the IPO process, conducting annual
	audits, providing business advice with respect to M&amp;A activities and various types of capital and debt financing transactions. Mr.&nbsp;Chan has served as a member of professional, government and regulatory committees, including the Hong Kong
	Stock Exchange Listing Committee, the Selection Committee for the first Legislative Council of the Hong Kong SAR and the Hong Kong Society of Certified Public Accountants. For the Hong Kong Society of Certified Public Accountants, he served as a
	member of its council, accounting standards committee and auditing standards committee, and was chairman of its China technical committee. Mr.&nbsp;Chan retired from PwC on June&nbsp;30, 2012.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Compensation of Directors and Executive Officers
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, we paid an aggregate of approximately $6.2 million in cash compensation to our executive officers.
	We paid an aggregate of $0.2 million in cash compensation to our non-executive directors other than Dr.&nbsp;Charles Zhang. In 2015, the total compensation expense recorded in our consolidated statements of comprehensive income was
	$7.4&nbsp;million. None of our directors have service contracts that provide for benefits upon termination of employment. For information regarding share-based compensation paid to officers and directors, see Item&nbsp;6, &#147;Directors, Senior
	Management and Employees&#151;Compensation of Directors and Executive Officers&#151;Share Incentive Plan&#148;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Employment
	Agreements with Executive Officers
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We have entered into employment agreements with each of our executive officers. Under these
	agreements with us, we may terminate an executive officer&#146;s employment for cause, at any time, for certain acts of such officer such as willful misconduct or gross negligence, repeated failure to perform substantially his duties, indictment or
	conviction for or confession of a felony, or any crime involving moral turpitude. In such case, such officer will not be entitled to receive payment of any severance benefits or other amounts by reason of termination other than accrued salary and
	vacation through the date of termination and such officer&#146;s right to all other benefits will terminate, except as required by any applicable law.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We may also terminate our employment agreements with our executive officers without cause upon thirty-day advance written notice. In such case
	of termination by us and also in a case where an executive officer voluntarily terminates his employment with us upon thirty-days&#146; advance written notice for &#147;good reasons,&#148; we are required to provide him with severance benefits equal
	to an amount up to six (6)&nbsp;months of his monthly base salary, provided that such executive officer complies with the &#147;employee non-competition, non-solicitation, confidential information and work product agreement&#148; during the
	severance period and execute a release agreement in the form requested by us. &#147;Good reasons&#148; include (i)&nbsp;any significant change in the executive officer&#146;s duties and responsibilities inconsistent in any material and adverse
	respect with his title and position, and (ii)&nbsp;any material breach of the employment agreement by us, including any reduction in the executive officer&#146;s base salary or our failure to pay to him any portion of his compensation.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In addition, each of our executive officers has entered into an employee non-competition, non-solicitation, confidential information, and work
	product agreement with us. Under these agreements, each of our executive officers has agreed to be bound by (i)&nbsp;non-competition restrictions during his employment and for one year after the termination of his or her employment or for such
	longer period during which we pay him or her any severance benefits, and (ii)&nbsp;non-solicitation restrictions during the non-competition period. Each executive officer has agreed to hold, both during and after the termination or expiry of his
	employment agreement, in strict confidence and not to use, except as required in the performance of his or her duties in connection with the employment, any of our confidential information or trade secrets, any confidential information or trade
	secrets of our clients or customers, or the confidential or proprietary information of any third party held by us in confidence. The executive officers have also agreed to disclose to us all inventions which they conceive and develop during the
	employment and to assign all right, title and interest in them to us and agreed not to assert any such rights against us.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Share
	Incentive Plan
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Changyou.com Limited 2008 Share Incentive Plan
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In December 2008, our Board of Directors and our shareholders adopted our 2008 Share Incentive Plan to attract, motivate and retain the best
	available personnel, provide additional incentives to our employees, directors and consultants and promote the success of our business. Our 2008 Share Incentive Plan provides for the issuance of up to 20,000,000 ordinary shares, of which 17,740,000
	are Class&nbsp;B ordinary shares and 2,260,000 are Class&nbsp;A ordinary shares.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	83
</P>

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
